author: mavster04
title: Golang SDK to Build Health App
description: Building a health app in a blockchain has lots of challenges. Aside from compliance, security, & data privacy, one has to learn blockchain-specific programming language. This makes onboarding harder.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to build a Rusk SDK to interact with their Hippocrades APIs. This opens up their health information system to developers who prefer to work with Golang (GO). This is a useful addition it could bring new Golang developers to Cardano and give an existing developer who prefers to code in Golang, or has integration needs with other Golang a platform to get started quickly. The SDK is geared towards Hippocrades and therefore not reusable immediately for the rest of Cardano ecosystem, therefore the reach is limited to some extent. It would have been good to see the proposer extend the scope to cover other parts of Cardano for which it could be used. However, the relatively low budget of $7k makes the reduced scope justified. The proposal scales to the extent that more developers will come to work on the Hippocrades apps. Note: The proposer has a similar proposal to build a Java SDK which I have also assessed. This proposal is in its entirety the same to the Java SDK proposal with only minor differences in the name of the SDK. For this reason, the text of this assessment is very similar as well to my assessment of the Java SDK
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has provided the list of individuals that are needed to deliver the proposal but has not identified who those individuals will be. The proposed however has a track record of delivering other parts of the Hippocrades app and states that access to a pool of developers who he can pull to work on this proposal. It would have been nice to see who those individuals are to be able to assess their technical capabilities. The budget of $7k is outlined and split between the tasks of a project lead, a backend developer, a python developer, and a documentation lead. The budget monthly rates for each of the tasks are competitive (e.g., $3k for a senior backend developer). The project is planned to be delivered within 1 month and this is quite realistic given that the team already have a Javascript SDK. The language differences between Golang and Javascript are still quite large, as Golang is typed language and Javascript is not, so there is some work involved in defining the type for all the variables which can identify some bugs in the existing javascript implementation and lead to some delays beyond the 1 month that has been allocated in this proposal. I think the proposal will be able to deliver, but it would have been nice to see a little more detail on the planning and recognition of the delivery risks. The proposer highlights that there is minimal risk to delivery. I suggest the proposer elaborates a little more on how the porting of the Javascript to Golang will be done. I think the proposer will be able to deliver, but there are risks of a delay. Note: The proposer has a similar proposal to build a Java SDK which I have also assessed. This proposal is in its entirety the same to the Java SDK proposal with only minor differences in the name of the SDK. For this reason, the text of this assessment is very similar as well to my assessment of the Java SDK
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer sets the time at 1 month to deliver the project after which the Golang SDK would have been delivered and open-sourced on Github. The project is quite short in terms of time, so it is unlikely that there will be intermediate steps to monitor progress. The proposer commits to pushing the development of the SDK for the community to monitor. The success is stated as the delivery of the SDK which is in with what the proposal set outs to deliver. The deliverable is objective and there should be no difficulty to audit the proposal. Note: The proposer has a similar proposal to build a Golang SDK which I have also assessed. Note: The proposer has a similar proposal to build a Java SDK which I have also assessed. This proposal is in its entirety the same to the Java SDK proposal with only minor differences in the name of the SDK. For this reason, the text of this assessment is very similar as well to my assessment of the Java SDK

f6_assessments.q0:
The Hippocrades Team has build an impressive suite of infrastructure products to enable app developers working with and for the health care industry to easily deploy applications that leverage the Cardano blockchain. This is a key piece of infrastructure that could prove very important for the adoption of Cardano. This particular proposal is requesting funding to build an SDK to allow Golang developers to quickly deploy an app on top of their existing infrastructure without the need to learn a different programming language.

The best part about it is that we don’t have to hope that the team will have the skills to deliver on an SDK as they have already built one for JavaScript that’s available today and linked in the proposal. The funding they are asking for in this proposal will go towards building the SDK for a new programming language, Golang (this proposal).

The team has 4 proposals in Fund 9 with the goal of building SDKs for developers working with languages to be able to deploy on their infrastructure with ease: Golang (this proposal), Java, Rust, and Python.

I understand and agree with the decision of the team to submit a different proposal for each programming language they intend to create an SDK for. This enables the community to choose and allocate funds to those it considers necessary, and also select one or a combination of multiple languages that are relevant and would be good investments for the treasury. This is not something that would have been possible in case of a single proposal that would have bundled all languages together.

The team has been very transparent about the fact that they have multiple proposals in Fund 9 all with the same objective, just for different programming languages, as they mention this fact in every one of the proposals. This should also help with discoverability by the voters, but my recommendation would be that if there will be a next time, they should consider including links from each proposal to all the others to help with navigation in case a voter or a community member wants to support multiple.

This set of proposals is clearly a very good fit for the Developer Ecosystem challenge because they directly answer the key guiding questions of the challenge: “what are the tools that we need to prioritize first” - those that will make the development process on Cardano the most seamless and effortless, and “how do we attract developers from outside of our current community to participate in Catalyst?” - by allowing them to build on Cardano in the language they are most comfortable with. By splitting up their plans for SDKs into multiple proposals and giving the community a chance to vote on exactly which ones they believe are the most relevant they also allow developers to directly answer the questions “what do developers want, and how do they get it from the Cardano dev ecosystem?”  Also, the Hippocrades project as a whole very much addresses the last guiding question of the challenge “what are enterprise dev managers looking for in order to be able to build out enterprise projects - either internal or commercial?”, at least as it applies to dev managers connected to the medical industry.

My assessment of this set of proposals in the Developer Ecosystem challenge is based on my experience as a project manager working directly with Cardano developers since July 2021. I have participated in almost all roles in Project Catalyst since February 2021, including as a previously funded proposer, and I’ve been involved with the Cardano development community and NFT community for about a year and a half.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team presents not only an impressive list of qualifications in the proposal but also a complete list of their already operational medical services infrastructure platform and a demo app. We don’t have to envision what developers could build with the new SDKs in the languages they are comfortable with, we actually get to see it. After inspecting it I can say it looks impressive, it seems to cover all the needs of a health professional while also maintaining a modern clean look.

The implementation plan is logical and makes sense within the context of the overall project. It’s for 5 weeks of development time and seems to cover all the necessary steps to successfully implement the SDK for Golang (this proposal). Each one of the 4 proposals in the set is estimated to take 5 weeks, meaning that in the case that all 4 proposals are funded, the total estimated completion time would be 20 weeks, given that the same team will be responsible for the execution of each SDK.

As this is a straightforward development project at an existing company, the budget breakdown only concerns itself with worker compensation for the month it is estimated that the development of the Golang SDK would take. The amounts seem very reasonable, low for Western standards but that shouldn’t be a problem since the team has indicated that they are in Africa (they haven’t directly specified this in the proposal, but since they are part of the Ariob Incubator / Iceaddis program I assume this is the case.)

The team members involved in the development of this particular part of the Hippocrades project are described in detail within the proposal, and the technical speciality of each is presented. They seem to collectively possess the skillset required to successfully deliver. However, because the proposal didn't link to any professional profiles (LinkedIn) or examples of previous work, I wasn't able to verify the claims around credentials and experience. But, even though they haven’t provided links for each individual separately, they did provide a very ample description of their project overall (Hippocrades) and numerous links to multiple resources about the project and showcasing the project.

All these factors make me very confident in the Hippocrades’ team's ability to deliver on the scope of this project if funded.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal is very clear in what it wants to achieve and what are its intended deliverables. This alone should help a lot with the auditing process. A clear roadmap for the project is presented and from that, the delivery date can be easily extrapolated and verified. The team states it plans to use GitHub to record and monitor its activities and deliverables, which should further simplify the verification process as that is an almost universal tool used by most programmers in our developer community. 

Given all this, I see this proposal (and this set of proposals) as being very easy to audit by any member of our community with the right technical skill set and knowledge of Golang (this proposal), Java, Rust or Python.

Note on the proposal set and the assessments:

I have verified the content of all 4 proposals using software that allows for snapshots of text and comparisons between snapshots (Scrivener). I did this to make sure the text of all proposals is the same before writing this assessment. They are indeed identical, only the name of the intended programming language differs between proposals. As such, I have assessed all 4 proposals as a set. Just as the text of the proposals, I have also changed the specific programming language in each one of my assessments and I’ve written “(this proposal),” where this needed to be highlighted.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal wants to create an SDK to cater to Golang developers to build Health App, and has already built a health infrastructure with APIs. By creating this software development kit for those who know the Golang programming language, these developers can then build this app without having to go learn new languages. I believe this proposal targets the challenge objectives well and can provide a lot of value to the Cardano ecosystem by encouraging developers to build their apps on Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: The team has provided extensive detailing on who are part of the team, their experience, and their areas of expertise. They are 10 man team that seem very capable of carrying out this project. They have provided a plan that includes a timeline and key milestones that is clear and easy to follow, although I feel like it’s possible to add more detailing and explanations to the key milestones. The budget breakdown is simple and straightforward, and uses sensible numbers, but in this section it is also possible to elaborate on the details, for example how the payscale was worked out. Overall, they show a strong plan and capability and I have no doubts that this team will be able to successfully complete this project, but they could strengthen their proposal further by helping us understand more about the procedure.
f6_assessments.q2: Audability wise this proposal is also very complete, with a clear code protocol and task and deliverables system on GitHub. They have also presented what success during development and as a project both look like using reasonable measurements. They are also part of the bigger ecosystem of Hippocrades which has a discord users can interact in. However, they didn’t specify any specfic public auditing channel for this particular project, whereas it would be great if there was an outlet where anyone can find news and updates about the progress. That said, the measurements and tools they have listed strongly show that they have what is needed to efficiently measure and audit this project and ensure the success of it.

f6_assessments.q0: The "Golang SDK to build Health App" proposal addresses the Developer Ecosystem challenge by building a health infrastructure with APIs for devs to easily create a health app. Currently it has a javascript SDK already and want to extend to SDK to cater to Golang developers. The Hippocrades team want to allow Golang developers to focus on building the health app without having to learn the language. The team has plan to build SDKs for other languages ie. Python, Rust and Java. With their infrastructure, other health apps developers can build their apps in Cardano without having to concern about security, industry standard, compliance and data privacy. Developers can just focus on what they are good at which is developing on Cardano and hence this proposal fits the challenge very well.  The risk in implementation is minimal as the logic and framework remain the same.
f6_assessments.q1: The team has provided a detailed plan (timeline and milestones) for 5 weeks after the project is funded. The budget breakdown looks plausible for each role although they should consider include the number of working hours in each month so that the pay rate can be determined. The core tech team is strong and their reputation is proven as they got selected for the Ariob incubator/ Iceaddis program and also a seedstar - FT X cardano blockchain challenge finalist. They will require for future funding as they still have tasks to complete over its infrastructure. The team has considered risk & challenges in deliverying the proposal and it is very likely that the team will complete the project successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The team has considered it a success once the Golang SDK go live and available in the Hippocrades infrastructure for developers. They have listed down KPIs/ metrics to measure project success as stable code, simple code, testable code, team velocity and knowledge share. The community can notice project progress on GitHub which show project status. The team has understood the challenge of developers need to develop the health app without having to learn the new programming language and hence they offer to help developers to easily create a health app by building a health infrastructure with APIs.

f6_assessments.q0: This suggestion is very helpful for developers. It's a software development kit (SDK) for those who already knows the Golang programming language. Once it's available, the Golang developer can focus on building the health app without having to learn another language. This will save developers time and effort. From there, encourage them to join and build the ever-growing Cardano ecosystem. With all the above reasons, I am confident that this project will effectively solve the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
Team information has been provided. Your team consists of many members. Based on what is provided, they have full knowledge, skills and experience in areas such as: programming, web development, blockchain,... . In particular, they have achieved certain successes: successfully deployed the decentralized healthcare platform Hippocrades, successfully built the Javascript SDK,... . Therefore, the team has the necessary conditions to implement this project. However, you mentioned that your group has more than 10 members, but you have only provided information of 3 members, I am very curious about the information of the remaining members. Hope you will add and clarify it. In addition, adding links to their Linkedin and Telegram profiles is also essential. It helps the above information become more transparent.
Detailed route has been provided specifically. Since you have experience in the previous project (JS SDK) you have done quite well in defining the route in this project. However, I have a question, how will you do the communication and marketing? During what time period? Besides, the budget is quite vague, people need to know exactly how the $7,500 money is spent. I have a few suggestions for you: calculate a budget based on the number of people involved in each job, the number of hours worked, the hourly rate,... . In addition, there should also be specific metrics to track the progress and success of the project. For example: there will be 300 people reaching each month, there are 5 projects applying Golang SDK per month,...
f6_assessments.q2:
In addition to the problems that I mentioned in the previous section. I think marketing and communication is also one of the risky challenges of the project. Hope you will have a way to communicate and attract people to this project.
Although the information provided is not really complete, the PAs can still rely on it to evaluate the success of this project. A big advantage is that you have experience in creating JS SDK and have Hippocrades support. I firmly believe this project can be done easily.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal tries to add Golang support for the Hippocrades healthcare infrastructure. The aim is to attract Go developers and facilitate their ability to build their own health apps without having to learn new programming languages. It aligns with the challenge settings and, if implemented, would ultimately add value to the Cardano ecosystem because, in theory, more health apps are going to be developed. However, I am a bit concerned about whether the Golang SDK support is premature or not. Looking at their roadmap on hippocrades.org, we can see that many SDKs are on the way before the reward system. I think it's more cost-efficient to delay the SDK support if they have to be re-updated again. It really depends on whether or not there will be any breaking changes after they implement the reward system. I hope the proposer could clarify more on this matter. Other than that, I strongly agree with the proposal contribution and am personally excited to see more healthcare usecases in Cardano. This proposal acts as a stepping stone as it makes development easier.
f6_assessments.q1: I am inclined to agree that the proposed plan would ensure smooth implementation. The proposers are the ones who developed the Hippocrades infrastructure, and they are the ones who understand the most how their modules and architecture work. They also have successfully supported JavaScript, so they have a knowledge base to assume the amount of work they have to put in for this proposal. The budget is broken down into items based on the amount of resources needed and the amount is reasonable. I applaud the proposer's initiative to emphasize QA and documentation too, since it supplements the aim of supporting new developers. However, since the proposer has proposed four different SDK support in this fund, I would like to see an explicit explanation of how they would manage all the projects simultaneously if they were all funded. Another improvement that would help the proposer is to add a buffer to their timeline to mitigate the risk of delivery delays, especially considering there might be different nuances within Javascript and Golang. Perhaps the proposer has already added this buffer time within their plan or, based on previous Javascript SDK, they are confident that it won’t take too much time. Finally, I am confused about the Python developer budget item. Why is it Python? Is it a typo and the proposer meant Go? Is Python the language Hippocrades is written in? A quick clarification about this would be helpful as well.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has provided enough information for us to audit. The success of the proposal is straightforward; the release of the Golang SDK for Hippocrades. We could track the project’s progress (tasks and deliverables) through the SDK Github repository that they will provide. Their five-week roadmap is also structured around milestones, which makes it easier to monitor whether or not the proposal is on-track or not. In the end, I am confident we can measure this proposal through the ways provided by the proposer above.

f6_assessments.q0: This project as proposed would have a high likelihood of a strong impact on achieving the goals of this challenge. This challenge seeks to develop tools for Developers to create apps on the cardano network. This team has developed the Hippocrates health  application framework on cardano. The purpose of this proposal is to create a golang SDK. This would enable golang developers and programmers to create apps using the Hippocrates framework.  This is a really powerful and useful tool to expand the user base of cardano. I would like to see this framework become widely adopted with dozens to hundreds of new applications on it for the next couple years. By moving Healthcare information to the blockchain and using this secure API framework, there could be dozens of different interconnected apps.  I believe this is at the heart of this challenge and therefore I'm giving this proposal score of 5.
f6_assessments.q1: This team has already developed the API and the framework first secure Healthcare ecosystem built on cardano. They have the experience with their framework, they  are skilled coders and programmers, and what they're seeking to do is incredibly feasible. They already have developed one SDK for their app and this proposal enables them to develop another for the golang language.  The budget is clear though not as detailed as others. The time frame is reasonable with clear milestones for development. The team's experience is clear and obvious and well-detailed. There are no issues regarding feasibility for this proposal in my mind. That is why I've given it a score of 5.
f6_assessments.q2: This team has experience developing much larger applications than this proposal. They have already developed a single SDK and so I know what it takes to do another one. They plan on using GitHub, and Publishing their  code in a transparent and open manner. They have experience doing sprints, they are well disciplined, and they have an existing process for code auditability.  The goal is clear and deliverable. They are committed to sharing their knowledge through collaborative meetings. They use GitHub to track Monitor and manage all of their coding activity. This proposal is highly auditable and very clear and that is why I have given it a score of 5.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is located in the Developer Ecosystem challenge. In this challenge the goal is to make it easier to onboard new developers, make it easier for developers to develop, increase developer productivity, attract high-caliber developers, and developers given ample resources to work on platforms that suit their interests.

The proposer is proposing to add a Golang SDK to Build Health App on top of Hippocrades, a healthcare infrastructure that is already built. Currently they have a SDK for JavaScript, and want to create an software development kit (SDK) for the Go language. The go language is quickly becoming one of the most popular languages out there and the impact this would have could be very big for Cardano. 

The medical industry is massive and in and of itself can bring big growth to Cardano usage, and Hippocrades has already built infrastructure for the medical industry on the Cardano blockchain.  However, what good is this protocol if there are no or little developers to work on applications to run on this secure/zero knowledge protocol? So the idea is to create SDK for various highly used and popular programming languages so more developers can easily create apps to run on the protocol. This has the ability to bring in new developers outside of the Cardano ecosystem into our ecosystem, as well as enable current developers on the Cardano blockchain that were not previously able to help build apps out to now be able to if they know this language. This would make it easier on developers as well as enable more developers to create applications on top of a protocol that is operating in extremely large industry. In effect this could bring more doctors onto the chain, as well as patients, nurses, and the like.

As far as scalability, this can expand out to create SDK's for pretty much any language out there.

This proposal effectively addresses the challenge
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer has considered any risks, and has concluded that risk is very minimal and I agree because the core of Hippocrades Infrastructure has already been built. The team has also built the JavaScript SDK as well so it's just a matter of building one on a separate language for which the logic and framework remain the same. They are simply requesting funding to create a golang SDK.

The plan/timeline is concise, broken down into milestones, and has time horizons for each major phase. The timeline for the plan is feasible and should be easily achievable. On top of their well laid out plan we see a budget that is, clear, well balanced with the amount of time and work needed to successfully complete the golang SDK, and is broken down for us nicely.

As far as the team is concerned, they have listed each member, provided detailed list of experience and skills of each member, but have provided no links to verify these things. However, the team at Hippocrades has proven track record, very big success, and have already shown the skill level, educational level, and experience level that they hold.  

Given experience and plan presented it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2:
Even though this project is simple, the proposer has still listed metrics that they will be following to gauge the success and progress of the project. These metrics are more then sufficient to keep track of this project as it moves through the plan to completion. Furthermore the proposer has let us know that:
"Tasks and deliverables of the Dev Team are placed in GitHub from which we track, monitor, manage activities that are pending, ongoing, and done."
so we also have a way for the community to keep track of the progress and success of this proposal.

The information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The idea is very interesting and fits very well with the goals of the challenge of building a health app on a blockchain that has a lot of challenges. For compliance, security and data privacy it is imperative that participants learn a blockchain-specific programming language. This makes referrals harder. To solve this problem Hippocrades built a health infrastructure with APIs for developers to easily create a health application. This is the solution that the author gave to this proposal. It already has a Javascript SDK now the author wants to create an SDK to serve the Golang developers. This proposal effectively solves the challenge, if funded can provide a good impact for the Cardano community to help the community grow stronger day by day. The core of the Hippocrades Infrastructure has already been built so the author was confident that their proposal would be risk-free.
f6_assessments.q1: The project implementation timeline is specifically listed by the author. The implementation time of this project is 5 weeks, the goals are listed in detail by the author of the work to be done for each phase. The progress of the project is completely trackable. The Golang SDK is a software development kit (SDK) for those who already know the Golang programming language. Once available, Golang developers can focus on building health apps without having to learn another language. The team has been building Healthcare Infrastructure in Cardano, so other developers will be encouraged to build their health apps in Cardano as well. The team spent many years building this infrastructure. The success of the project is clearly described by the author, which is related to the challenge of the campaign.
f6_assessments.q2: KPIs are clearly defined, the author has been building healthcare applications for the past 5 years, this is a project that they have put a lot of effort into. This project's funding budget is $7.500 less than 20% of the entire challenge's budget. The budget is broken down by the author into the amounts that need to be spent in the 4 phases of their project implementation. The Hippocrades team built a decentralized healthcare infrastructure for Cardano. The author has a strong team to carry out this project. It is recommended to assign specific tasks to each member, they are highly specialized people, the identity of team members is easy to verify. The proposal also assigns tasks to specific members that are relevant to their current work. This is a brand new project and waiting to be funded.

solution: Hippocrades has built a health infrastructure with APIs for devs to easily create a health app. Currently, it has a Javascript SDK already. We want to create an SDK to cater Golang developers.
experience: We are from the Hippocrades Teamthat has built a decentralized healthcare infrastructure for Cardano. We have been selected in the 1st batch of the Ariob Incubator / Iceaddis program in Africa which is supported by Cardano for high-potential startups. A Dev Portal is already set
